In Julia, Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".

In Julia, you can achieve this using the built-in `replace()`, `lowercase()` and `strip()`. Here's a function to do exactly that:

```julia
function clean_column(col::String)
    return replace(lowercase(strip(col)), r"[ _\-]" => "_")
end
```
This function first strips leading, trailing whitespaces from the string using `strip()`. Then it converts all characters to lower case using `lowercase()`. After that, it uses a regular expression to find and replace all spaces (" "), hyphens ("-"), and any number of leading or trailing underscores with a single underscore. The result is a cleaned column name. 

Please note that the built-in string functions like `replace()`, `lowercase()` are part of standard library and hence don't need importing before using them in code. 

Also, you can use the function by passing your column name as below:
```julia
cleaned_column = clean_column("My Column")
println(cleaned_column) # Outputs "my_column"
```
